description.narrative: Handelspolitiskt ubildningsinstitut för afrikanska länder med fokus på de fattigaste länderna i samarbete med Lunds Universitet. Fas II och Fas I avslutades 2011.

Trade Policy learning institute for African countries with a focus on the Least Developed Countries. Implemented in cooperation with Lund University. This is Phase II and Phase I was finished in early 2011.

The overall goal of trapca's offering is poverty reduction through improved integration in the world economy of LDCs and low-income sub-Saharan countries through enhancement of capacity (knowledge and skills) to negotiate and implement pro-poor trade policies and trade laws. The programme objectives included: -Developing trade policy skills by conducting short courses in trade policy and international trade negotiations.-Having an internationally anchored Centre with both African and internationally reputable trade institutional linkages.-Organising top-level thematic and topical conferences on trade policy and law.-Developing and delivering a Master of Science Programme in Trade Policy and Trade Law. -Creating an efficient and effective network of a community of African and international trade experts to serve as faculty members. -Building human and physical infrastructure capacity adequately to meet programme quality and service delivery standards and expectations.

participating-org.narrative: ESAMI/Eastern and Southern African Management Institute

description.narrative:
Trapca's academic output during the period was well in line with the commitments made in the programme document and the centre has lived up to its guiding principles of academic excellence, African ownership, targeting of students from the poorest countries and striving towards gender balance. During the period in question trapca offered short courses (foundation and specialised, on-site and e-learning), intermediate short courses and advanced courses. Short courses Short courses consist of foundation and specialised courses. In line with the RAF, over the period 2011-2016, trapca was expected to attain a total of 3,400 participant weeks, based on an annual output of 680 participant weeks. Trapca rained a total of 489 participants at the foundation level, 45% of which through e-learning. Actual number of courses was exceeded with the attainment of 5,392 participant weeks as indicated in Figure 1 below
Advanced courses Trapca has a set of ten advanced modules that are designed to enhance the analytical competences of the participants with the overall objective of boosting their critical, research and rigorous diagnoses of trade policy issues. Cumulatively for the period under review, trapca was expected to attain 7200 participant weeks and this was in total exceeded by 2,330 participant weeks. There was also excellent performance among the students who participated in the advanced modules during the period under review as evidenced by an average pass rate of 96 percent. Figure 7: Participant Weeks Attained in Advanced Courses, 2011-2016
Post Graduate Advanced Diploma Participants who successfully complete five advanced modules inclusive of TRP 501 and TRP 502 are awarded a Post- Graduate Diploma in International Trade Policy and Trade Law Advanced. Over the period under review, a total of 128 students attained this award. Master of Science Degree The Masters programme is accredited by Lund University, Sweden and it is awarded to those students who successfully complete all the advanced modules, plus a thesis that is equivalent to two modules, making a total of twelve modules for the entire programme. In line with the RAF, trapca was annually expected to graduate 15 students with the Masters Degree during each of the years under review. This meant that by end of 2016, trapca was expected to have graduated a total of 90 students. This overall target was surpassed by 20 students, i.e. the total number was 110.
Unexpected result (challenge) In an attempt to increase trapca's financial sustainability fees were introduced. In the past all courses had been offered free of charge, including travel, accommodation and meals when on-site at ESAMI/trapca in Arusha. The introduction of fees had a negative impact on attendance and around 50% of the students dropped out. Upon a request by trapca a decision was taken by Sida to re-introduce full funding for participants from LDCs. Unexpcted activity (positive) Following the 2013 MTR trapca introduced a specialised e-learning course on trade and gender: Trade Policy, Gender and Poverty Alleviation.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
